body:
As long as ncurses are used, it should be pretty straightforward to add option for showing the _statusline_ and the _cmdline_ at the top (under the tab list if any) instead of at the bottom.

This is a feature I've been waiting for for more than 6 years. I have all important stuff in all applications at the top and _(n)vim_ is the only one, which forces me to often look at the very bottom of my screen which causes unnecessary neck and back pain even after a short-time use on a notebook.

:+1: 

But I agree with @elmart

I've been delaying dicussing this until later, but a refactor in the command-line code may be required for the first release. The reason is that command-line, just like interactive ex mode, uses a completely isolated mechanism for input and redraw, and making that play nicely with msgpack-rpc redraw events could be very challenging

Before evolving the discussion, what do you guys think of this:

``` vim
function! SetupCommandLine()
  if exists('g:enhanced_command_line')
    inoremap <buffer> <silent> <esc> <esc>:q<cr>
  endif
endfunction

function! TeardownCommandLine()
  if exists('g:enhanced_command_line')
    iunmap <buffer> <silent> <esc>
  endif
  unlet g:enhanced_command_line
endfunction

au CmdwinEnter * call SetupCommandLine()
au CmdwinLeave * call TeardownCommandLine()
nnoremap <silent> : :let g:enhanced_command_line = 1<cr>q:i
```

Currently we can't make the command window a full replacement for the command line(see `:help command-line-window` for limitations), but I'm showing this because it has crossed my mind the idea of making command line just a special mode of the command-window. Advantages of this:
- Simplification(one less mode the editor can be in)
- Remove a lot of code in favor of reusing existing facilities to achieve the same funcitonality
- Make the command-line more easily customizable
- Transparent integration with UIs over msgpack-rpc

Any thoughts? I'm interested in reading what @ZyX-I thinks of this(especially possible implications)

That vimscript snippet was just to play with the idea of using a command window like interface for normal command line.

In other words: If we take the current command window, enhance with command line mappings and behavior(activated when pressing `:`, would it be a viable alternative to the current command line?

From the code maintenance POV, it seems to be a good simplification(possible removal of ex_getln.c?), but I'm also interested in knowing what users think of the idea.

I can't answer at once. It needs some thinking. Probably, we would need to have a prototype of it to really grasp how it would feel, and find unseen limitations/potentialities.
We would still have the current command window. The idea is to give it some enhancements(enabled when invoked with `:`) that made it a drop-in replacement for the command line

There are two things regarding command line/window that I've always felt far from perfect:
- Not being able to press Esc in command line to go backwards and correct a typo, and having to press C-F to go to command window, when all I want is normal mode, but for the single command line.
- Not having command completion when in command window's insert mode, editing a previous command.

Now, imagine we have an improved command-window, which can be launched two ways (single-line and multi-line). And that command window's insert mode is able to completely emulate previous command mode, completions and all.

Then, I would have my problems solved. Normal mode in command line just pressing esc. And command completion in command window. What do you think?

Thats what I have been imagining, though it is already possible to use completion in the command window(did you try pressing TAB in insert mode? it shows a insert-mode menu with the completions you would get in the command line). The only thing it is not emulated in command window insert mode is history search(with `<up>`/`<down>` with what has been typed so far

> Then, I would have my problems solved. Normal mode in command line just pressing esc. And command completion in command window. What do you think?

Not sure if we should change the default behavior of the command line(eg: make <esc> go into normal mode) because existing mappings may depend on it. What you desire is already possible though, you can simply remap `<esc>` in the command line, something like `cnoremap <esc> <c-f>`

Here's an improved version of the previous snippet, this one makes sure normal command window isn't affected:

``` vim
function! EnableImprovedCommandLine()
  nnoremap <silent> : :let g:improved_command_line = 1<cr>q:i
endfunction

function! DisableImprovedCommandLine()
  nunmap :
endfunction

function! SetupImprovedCommandLine()
  if exists('g:improved_command_line')
    inoremap <buffer> <silent> <esc> <esc>:q<cr>
  else
    call DisableImprovedCommandLine()
  endif
endfunction

function! TeardownImprovedCommandLine()
  if exists('g:improved_command_line')
    iunmap <buffer> <esc>
    unlet g:improved_command_line
  else
    call EnableImprovedCommandLine()
  endif
endfunction

au CmdwinEnter * call SetupImprovedCommandLine()
au CmdwinLeave * call TeardownImprovedCommandLine()
call EnableImprovedCommandLine()
```

Ok. One small itch I have about this:

To me, command mode and insert mode are conceptually different. In particular, there are mapppings I want in command mode I don't want in insert mode. So, I understand we would be emulating command mode reusing implementation of insert mode, but not dropping conceptual command mode. 

But then, how would things like command mode mappings work? I suppose a command mode mapping would translate into an insert mode mapping restricted to a particular buffer (command line buffer). Am I right? Do you preview any difficulties down that path?

If I may, I'd really like to add a request for a feature that would spare me of sereval lines of code in a Neovim plugin I've made for workspace management. For now I need to implement split handling, but I haven't done it because statusline and tabline seem to work differently from each other. Here's a gif that shows what I mean:

![split](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7888397/89704665-40f7ee00-d92c-11ea-868f-019d40bbe450.gif)

So what I mean is that when performing the `:split` command, Neovim creates an independent statusline for each split buffer, but keeps the same tabline. I know there must be a reason for this, but it would really improve the next version of my plugin if the user had the option of disabling the creation of a separate statusline for each split. 

The way the plugin already works is this. By creating a project file such as


![Screenshot from 2020-08-08 04-08-09](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7888397/89704722-d1cec980-d92c-11ea-91a5-27191484806d.png)

NVPM then renders the statusline to show the buffer-list created in the project file as shown in the code snippet above. The tabline, on the other hand, will render both the workspace list and the tablist. 

In the next version of NVPM plugin, I intend to implement the feature of creating splits in the project file, such as

![split](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7888397/89704764-4b66b780-d92d-11ea-8409-5048e11ac9bd.png)

where the user could tell NVPM to split them horizontally or vertically. But it's of great importance if Neovim doesn't create two statuslines for each split, as shown at the end of the gif.

I don't know how hard would be to implement it or even if it's already possible somehow. Any help?

with regards,
